pr_title: [homekit] New accessories Garage Door Opener and Outlet

timeline.message:
incorporate J-N-K review

Signed-off-by: Eugen Freiter <freiter@gmx.de>

align on heating current and target mode naming

Signed-off-by: Eugen Freiter <freiter@gmx.de>

add support for Outlet and GarageDoorOpener. incorporate feedback from reviews

Signed-off-by: Eugen Freiter <freiter@gmx.de>

timeline.bodyText: So it won't return the configuration value if no default value is provided? That doesn't seem right...
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: Didn't think about that. Another way would be to check for value != null and catch ClassCastException instead of trying to check the class before.
replies.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText: Well the ClassCastException wouldn't occur in this method but it would occur on the caller when it attempts to cast the return value into what it thinks it should be.
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: In fact, defaultValue could be annotated as @NonNull at least in the use-cases we have so far.
replies.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText:
if defaultValue is null we dont know to which class to cast to. So,  it must be not null. we can add @NotNull.
alternative would be to create separate methods like getAccessoryConfigurationAsString, getAccessoryConfigurationAsInteger
currently we have only these 2 cases: String and Integer and cannot think of anything else.
it is configuration from metadata - so, it will be either String "" or number.
Switch MyFan "My Fan" { homekit="Fan.v2", alexa="Fan" [ type="oscillating", speedSteps=3 ] }
replies.author: yfre

replies.bodyText: I think the generic version is better. is theer any reason why we can't add null-annotations to these classes`?
replies.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText: NonNull will not hurt here. added.
replies.author: yfre

timeline.message:
mark defaultValue as NonNull

Signed-off-by: Eugen Freiter <freiter@gmx.de>

mark defaultValue as NonNull

Signed-off-by: Eugen Freiter <freiter@gmx.de>
